liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton and Shadow Sport Minister Anne Ruston have criticised Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's plan to talk with state and territory leaders about potentially giving Australians a day off if the Matildas win the Women's World Cup. In a joint statement, Dutton and Ruston say the Coalition will instead commit $250 million in funding over four years for community sporting infrastructure, if re-elected. "The prime minister's proposal of a one-off public holiday to celebrate the incredible success of the Matildas comes at a potential cost to the economy of $2 billion; not to mention sidelining the recent triumphs of other female teams in the Netball World Cup and the Ashes. It is a stunt which will have no legacy impact," they say. "The prime minister has tried to make the Matildas' success all about him. But we think there is a better way. We are opposed to Mr Albanese's public holiday and today we are announcing a policy that will instead make a lasting difference to the community and the lives of our young people. "This is a better and more lasting proposal than the Prime Minister's public holiday ego trip. It will mean better outcomes over the decades ahead for millions of young girls and boys across the country." Dutton and Ruston say the Liberal Party's investment wouldn't be contingent on state or territory government investment, but they would be encouraged "to match our investment to bring the total to $500 million". They say they are committed to the proposal, even if the Matildas don't win the World Cup.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Peter Dutton and Anne Ruston say a proposed Matildas public holiday is a 'stunt' and 'ego trip' by the PM

props.alt: A bald man wearing glassed and a suit and tie stands in front of an Australian flag

children.content: (ABC News: Dave Sciasci)

Opposition Leader Peter Dutton and Shadow Sport Minister Anne Ruston have criticised Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's plan to talk with state and territory leaders about potentially giving Australians a day off if the Matildas win the Women's World Cup.
In a joint statement, Dutton and Ruston say the Coalition will instead commit $250 million in funding over four years for community sporting infrastructure, if re-elected.

"The prime minister's proposal of a one-off public holiday to celebrate the incredible success of the Matildas comes at a potential cost to the economy of $2 billion; not to mention sidelining the recent triumphs of other female teams in the Netball World Cup and the Ashes. It is a stunt which will have no legacy impact," they say.

"The prime minister has tried to make the Matildas' success all about him. But we think there is a better way. We are opposed to Mr Albanese's public holiday and today we are announcing a policy that will instead make a lasting difference to the community and the lives of our young people.

"This is a better and more lasting proposal than the Prime Minister's public holiday ego trip. It will mean better outcomes over the decades ahead for millions of young girls and boys across the country."

Dutton and Ruston say the Liberal Party's investment wouldn't be contingent on state or territory government investment, but they would be encouraged "to match our investment to bring the total to $500 million".
They say they are committed to the proposal, even if the Matildas don't win the World Cup.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Brad Ryan in Washington DC There are plenty of unanswered questions about the origins of a court document — dismissed by a court as "fictitious " — which lists new charges against Donald Trump. As we reported earlier, Reuters published a copy of the document, saying it had briefly appeared on the website of Georgia's Fulton County court, before the court's clerk said it wasn't genuine. Fulton County — Georgia's largest county — is where a grand jury is currently considering whether to indict the president on alleged election interference attempts. In a statement released a short time ago, Trump lawyers Drew Findling and Jennifer Little say: "The Fulton County District Attorney's Office has once again shown that they have no respect for the integrity of the grand jury process. This was not a simple administrative mistake. "A proposed indictment should only be in the hands of the District Attorney's Office, yet it somehow made its way to the clerk's office and was assigned a case number and a judge before the grand jury even deliberated. "This is emblematic of the pervasive and glaring constitutional violations which have plagued this case from its very inception." It's now almost 6pm in Georgia, but the grand jury remains in the courtroom. That could — but doesn’t necessarily — mean an after-hours indictment is coming tonight. "I guess you'll have to wait and see," Judge Robert McBurney told reporters at the court, according to the New York Times.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: That 'fictitious' court document has raised the ire of Donald Trump's lawyers

children.content: By Brad Ryan in Washington DC

props.alt: Donald Trump in a suit and tie, holding an umbrella and talking to reporters who are holding microphones

children.content: (AP: Alex Brandon)
There are plenty of unanswered questions about the origins of a court document —
dismissed by a court as "fictitious
— which lists new charges against Donald Trump.
As we reported earlier, Reuters published a copy of the document, saying it had briefly appeared on the website of Georgia's Fulton County court, before the court's clerk said it wasn't genuine.
Fulton County — Georgia's largest county — is where a grand jury is currently considering whether to indict the president on alleged election interference attempts.
In a statement released a short time ago, Trump lawyers Drew Findling and Jennifer Little say:
"The Fulton County District Attorney's Office has once again shown that they have no respect for the integrity of the grand jury process. This was not a simple administrative mistake.

"A proposed indictment should only be in the hands of the District Attorney's Office, yet it somehow made its way to the clerk's office and was assigned a case number and a judge before the grand jury even deliberated.
"This is emblematic of the pervasive and glaring constitutional violations which have plagued this case from its very inception."
It's now almost 6pm in Georgia, but the grand jury remains in the courtroom.
That could — but doesn’t necessarily — mean an after-hours indictment is coming tonight.
"I guess you'll have to wait and see," Judge Robert McBurney told reporters at the court, according to the New York Times.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Passengers onboard a Malaysian Airlines flight from Sydney to Kuala Lumpur have criticised the response time of authorities after a man allegedly made threats onboard and forced the plane to turn back. Australian Federal Police officers described it as an emergency and boarded the plane, arresting the 45-year-old who they said was expected to be charged. Passengers were finally allowed to leave the plane after around three hours on the tarmac. Passenger Velutha Parambath says he felt like a hostage during the incident. "Speaking with fellow passengers, the fact that we were left at the end of the runway — with fire engines and everything surrounding us every 10, 20 minutes but no one getting in and taking this guy — it may be protocol, but that was the scariest bit," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Charges are expected after a man was arrested for allegedly making threats onboard a flight from Sydney

children.content: Passengers onboard a Malaysian Airlines flight from Sydney to Kuala Lumpur have criticised the response time of authorities after a man allegedly made threats onboard and forced the plane to turn back.
Australian Federal Police officers described it as an emergency and boarded the plane,
arresting the 45-year-old who they said was expected to be charged

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, welcome to the ABC Markets Blog. Wall Street closed higher, boosted by technology stocks as chipmaker Nvidia jumped on optimism about AI. The Nasdaq put on 1 per cent and the S & P500 rose 0.6 per cent. The Australian dollar fell to 64.55 US cents overnight because of fears China's largest private property developer Country Garden could default. Yesterday, the Australian share market hit a four-week low on worries about the problems in China's property industry. Companies reporting profit results today include vaccine maker CSL, jobs website Seek and Treasury Wine Estates. And the latest data on wages will be out, as well as the minutes from the Reserve Bank's board meeting earlier this month. Join us for all today's market's news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US stocks rise, Australian dollar slumps

children.content: Good morning, welcome to the ABC Markets Blog.
Wall Street closed higher, boosted by technology stocks as chipmaker Nvidia jumped on optimism about AI.
The Nasdaq put on 1 per cent and the S
P500 rose 0.6 per cent.
The Australian dollar fell to 64.55 US cents overnight because of fears China's largest private property developer Country Garden could default.
Yesterday, the Australian share market hit a four-week low on worries about the problems in China's property industry.
Companies reporting profit results today include vaccine maker CSL, jobs website Seek and Treasury Wine Estates.
And the latest data on wages will be out, as well as the minutes from the Reserve Bank's board meeting earlier this month.
Join us for all today's market's news.
